body: #1992 was only merged to trunk, too. Should this really go into `0.10.1`? If yes, I can open one PR for both together.

@harshach 
We can run these tests in two way, locally on the laptop and on travis-ci.
- On my laptop I was able to get 138 out of 149 to pass
- On travis-ci I was able to run only 124 tests(timeout issues) out of these 88 passed. The failures seem to be timing related.
  https://travis-ci.org/raghavgautam/kafka/builds/171502069

For the enabling travis-ci, we need community consensus and I will start a discussion for this.

Yes, thanks for the feedback on this!
@guozhangwang - Sure thing.  I attempted opening the PR against the 0.10.1 branch but it looked like there were a lot of conflicts, is there another approach ?

You can try 1) checkout 0.10.1 first and checkout a new branch from there, and 2) use `git cherry-pick` to pull in that commit from trunk, 3) upon showing conflicts, fixing them forward, 3) `git commit` to create a new PR.

Thanks for the PR. A couple of things:
- 2.12.0 final was published to Maven recently, so it makes sense to depend on that directly.
- 2.12 requires Java 8 while Kafka requires Java 7 so we need to ensure that this change doesn't cause issues when building with Java 7. Have you tested that?

Currently all the dependent libraries are only available as compiled against RC2, I suspect people will start working on publishing 2.12.0 binaries but until then I figured it was better to get something going than wait.  Kafka is a transient dependency in reactive-kafka (via scalatest-embedded-kafka) so they can't be published until Kafka is.

When building I get `target is deprecated: -target:jvm-1.7 is deprecated, forcing use of jvm-1.8`, kafka with 2.12 will also have to be java8 (whereas the 2.11 version is fine with java7).  I would expect the 'release' version of kafka would continue to the be the 2.11 version but the full range of artifacts for 2.10, 2.11 and 2.12 be published so dependencies can be satisfied.
I'll be taking a look at this.
It may be that the restoration consumer ignore this setting.

LGTM. Thanks for the patch! By the way, a quick note on conventions. Usually we prefix the title of  minor patches like this with "MINOR: ". More serious bugs or improvements are usually accompanied by a JIRA, and we then use the ticket number as the prefix (e.g. "KAFKA-3299: Fix blah blah"). If you'd like to start working on larger patches, ping me or someone on the dev list with your apache id, and we'll add you as a contributor so that you can assign JIRAs to yourself.
LGTM. Thanks for the patch!
@hachikuji : Thanks . I'll follow this conventions in my future PRs. My apache id is himani1

Doh! super good catch @hachikuji .

I ran the system test locally and it reproduced exactly.
Investigated and found that we made another mistake WRT `.requestUpdate()` üò¢ 

I turned on TRACE logging of VerifiableProducer and found that it stops requesting update of metadata after it received following response from the broker, which is incomplete as the leader of partition 0 is missing, then it never continue producing accumulated records even though broker failovered successfully:

```
[2016-11-02 07:48:12,455] DEBUG Updated cluster metadata version 68 to Cluster(id = hbf5ulUERN642ViwSrvdxQ, nodes = [worker1:9092 (id: 2 rack: null)], partitions = [Partition(topic = test_topic, partition = 0, leader = none, replicas = [1,2,], isr = [])]) (org.apache.kafka.clients.Metadata)
```

This is because we made this change: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1707/commits/fdb0984a308001041892e3347ba1919d27ce9e6f#diff-499d1af91cfaf42966a8e2e485a1b4b9L180

`Metadata.add()` triggers `requestUpdate()` whenever the added partition is missing in the current list but in this case, the topic-partition was already added previously so no one will call `requestUpdate()`.

Reverted `requestUpdate()` for unknown leader partitions 48f598f and the system tests turns to passing.
So in the end   fdb0984 couldn't reduce even single line from production code :(

@kawamuray Good find and thanks for investigating.

@gwenshap Actually the behavior is intentional. Usually people are expecting to receive the `WakeupException` when calling `wakeup()` (e.g. because they want to shutdown), which means there's always a race where you might accidentally call it in between calls to `poll()`. So this behavior ensures the user that they won't "miss" a wakeup call. Does that seem reasonable to you?

Is this change really worth it? It seems to make the code less readable and the benefit is unclear.
Thanks for the review @shikhar. There's a separate PR (https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2100) for KAFKA-4356. I addressed the other comments.

The motivation is from scala 2.12;

> Eta-expansion (conversion of a method to a function value) of zero-args methods has been deprecated, as this can lead to surprising behavior (#5327).

See http://www.scala-lang.org/news/2.12.0

So it may be less readable but correct trumps readable ;)  (2.13 won't perform the expansion at all which is why it has been deprecated)

Neither the quote or the PR make it clear what the surprising behaviour is though. And the code before this PR is correct, so the change is not really about correctness in this context. Finally, because no-one is checking for 2.12 warnings, there is nothing preventing such usages from reoccurring. In fact, it's likely that they will. So, I'm not too keen on making this change right now. We'll have to do it before we support 2.13, but there's no rush really.

The code after the PR is also correct and simply removes the automatic eta-expansion that is happening with 2.10 and 2.11.

The surprising bit is that if you have `def foo() = ???` then `foo` could mean `foo()` or `foo _` depending on the context, in 2.13 you will need to do `foo _`.  We could use the `() => foo()` construct instead of `foo _` but thats even more noisy.

https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2088 adds a 2.12 build, the number of warnings under 2.12 is quite large.  This change resolves the eta-expansion warnings.

@hachikuji @shikhar @kkonstantine This slipped in with https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2096 where I was thinking the regex would simply require at least one character, but the default regex, `[^/]+` already does that. Instead, this was more liberal and would match even `/` characters, which meant it was matching a bunch of patterns previously handled by other methods. This resulted in 405 Method Not Supported errors because the routing was targeting the wrong methods.

Thanks for the review @ewencp. I addressed the nits and left a question on the constructor visibility for `SystemTime`.

With regards to `QueryableStateIntegrationTest`, I was able to reproduce it locally after a few successful runs. Seems like there is an error acquiring a lock (it seems like there is a timestamp in the store name):

``` text
Caused by: org.rocksdb.RocksDBException: IO error: lock /var/folders/nv/h6d0v4151m74j_9qlc4cg6bc0000gn/T/qs-test5092372324958375949/queryable-state-3/2_0/windowed-word-count-store-stream-three-3/windowed-word-count-store-stream-three-3-201611070000/LOCK: No locks available
    at org.rocksdb.RocksDB.open(Native Method)
    at org.rocksdb.RocksDB.open(RocksDB.java:184)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.state.internals.RocksDBStore.openDB(RocksDBStore.java:189)
```

Full output in the following gist:

https://gist.github.com/ijuma/32001cef1a0fe6e8479600135ec69e40

@dguy, any ideas why we'd get the failure above?

@ismael - Looking at the stack trace it would seem the group has rebalanced, but at least one of the StreamThreads hasn't stopped yet and still owns the lock for that store. Will have to see if i can reproduce.

@miguno @guozhangwang @dguy @enothereska
LGTM except @becketqin 's comments.

A general question I would like to ask is that, what should we expect / tell users to do in the exception handler and in `getRuntime().addShutdownHook`? I think in general users should be able to call `streams.close` in the exception handler as well as shutdown hook (note this is per thread) since here may be more than one thread in the instance and when one of it abruptly stops, they may want to stop all other threads as well; however, I'm not sure if it is a good pattern to call `System.exit()` in the exception handler, since this is per thread, and instead we would only call `System.exit()` after the streams instance is completed shutdown.

For Kafka Server, here is the common recommended pattern:
1. In `Kafka.scala`, where the main function is triggered to start the `KafkaServerStartable` class, the Shutdown hook is set to call `KafkaServerStartable.shutdown`, which is mainly for catching ctrl-c; it calls `System.exit(1)` on catching any exceptions while calling `KafkaServerStartable.startup`.
2. In `KafkaServerStartable`, similar to above any exceptions will be caught with `System.exit(1)`; and in `shutdown` it will catch exceptions with `Runtime.getRuntime.halt(1)` to avoid deadlocks.

This is because the shutting down logic is caught in two functions `shutdown` and `awaitShutdown`, whereas `shutdown` only sets the flag and `awaitShutdown` is called after the `start` function.

As for Kafka Streams, I feel it is better to execute a similar pattern; more specifically, say we have not have exposed APIs to query the state of the instance (e.g. like if the instance is shutdown). I.e. 1) either you can implement the pattern indicated in the blog post where the `main` function thread just call `streams.start` and then call `streams.close` before exiting, or using the shutdown hook to call `streams.close`, or 2) keep the main thread alive after calling `streams.close` and then have a similar `awaitShutdown` function by polling on the instance state in the end before exiting, and then optionally add the per-thread exception handler to call `streams.close`.

As for the report scenario in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4366, where the streams code may be only part of the whole `main` function logic, but the whole app still wants to exit when the streams have any exceptions, they can possibly fall into the second case above, where exception handler should only call `streams.close` and the main function wait on streams state to close and then `System.exit()`. What do you think? @dguy @enothereska @mjsax
@jcustenborder @guozhangwang @dguy @enothereska @miguno @hjafarpour
OKÔºå I fix the comments problem, thanks @becketqin @guozhangwang

I think I realize that the original idea of splitting the functionalities of the timestamp extractor and  the handler (for messages with invalid timestamps) might have been the better idea:  The timestamp extractor should only be responsible for extracting the timestamp, whereas the handler (which would be used e.g. inside `addRawRecords`) should only be responsible for determining what happens to records with invalid timestamps.

At the moment, we are in the unfortunate situation where, for example, the (new) timestamp extractor is effectively identical to the default extractor with regards to timestamp extraction.  The only difference is that it also logs a WARN message (which arguably is ok -- e.g. it may log information to say "Hey, I came across a message that doesn't include a timestamp, and in my case I won't do anything about that and return a negative timestamp as-is, but at least I can let you know") saying "this message will be dropped" (and this wording/information is wrong, because, based on its local knowledge, it can't determine whether or not any downstream code will or will not drop the message).
@guozhangwang updated to remove the `dirtyKeys.remove(..)` from evict

If we are going to go with this approach, i'm wondering if we should change the signature of `TimestampExtractor.extract` to: `long extract(ConsumerRecord<Object, Object> record, long currentStreamTime)` - this at least gives the user the ability to use the stream time in the event that the time can't be extracted from the record.
